raw.title: How to Write a Thesis
raw.author: Umberto Eco
contexts:
“Use colors,” Eco insisted, when marking a passage.
“Use abbreviations to emphasize the relevance of information,” “Use abbreviations to designate the passages you must reread,” “Supplement the underlining with adhesive page markers”

“Writing a thesis,” Eco wrote, “requires a student to organize ideas and data, to work methodically, and to build an ‘object’ that in principle will serve others.
In reality, the research experience matters more than the topic.”

Each type of index card should have a different color, and should include in the top right corner abbreviations that cross-reference one series of cards to another, and to the general plan.
The result is something majestic.

Eco has acknowledged this throughout his career.
Whether writing about Thomas Aquinas, James Bond, fascism, or semiotics, he has consistently succeeded in entertaining and informing his readers at the same time.

Eco was aware of this predicament.
As a university professor, he knew that the majority of students in Italian universities seldom attended classes, that very few of them would continue to write and do research, and that the degree they eventually earned would not necessarily improve their social conditions.

It was a momentous transformation, as Eco recognized in his introduction to the book: “Today the Italian university is a university for the masses.
Students of all social classes arrive from a variety of high schools.”
Eco stresses the advantages of what he defines as academic humility, that is, the willingness to “listen with respect to anyone, without this exempting us from pronouncing our value judgments.”
commentaries: The author cites Eco's practical advice on organizing research materials as enduring and methodologically significant, even amid technological change.
The author highlights Eco’s view that the value of a thesis lies in the disciplined process of research rather than the final topic, framing it as a formative educational experience.
The author interprets Eco’s filing system as a philosophical practice—an ordering of the mind that values procedure over outcome and cultivates accuracy and intellectual pleasure.
The author notes Eco’s broader literary and intellectual approach, using his thesis guide as an extension of his lifelong commitment to making humanities discourse engaging and accessible.
The author references Eco’s recognition of systemic educational challenges, portraying the book as a response to democratized higher education without compromising rigor.
The author cites Eco’s own words to underscore his awareness of the social expansion of higher education and his commitment to inclusive academic standards.
The author presents Eco’s concept of academic humility as a core ethical principle in scholarly work, balancing openness with critical judgment.

raw.author: Kant
contexts: For Kant, aesthetics and judgment were based on disinterestedness: they could not be programmed, only experienced.

we cannot write a thesis on Kant, Freud, or Marx
commentaries: The author references Kant to emphasize the non-programmable, experiential nature of aesthetic judgment, aligning it with the creative process of thesis writing.
Kant is referenced as a canonical authority on the concept of freedom, presented as a model for grounding abstract ideas in the work of a single philosopher.
The author cites Kant as an example of a philosopher whose original texts must be consulted in the original language to avoid misrepresentation through translation.
